title: Gower Surf & Coasteer
tagline: Wales' original AONB - catching waves and exploring cliffs on Britain's first Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty
highlights: Surfing at Llangennith - Wales' best surf beach
suitableFor: Active couples and friends who enjoy outdoor adventures and aren't afraid of a bit of a challenge. Must be comfortable in the water.
notSuitableFor: Those with limited mobility, a strong aversion to cold water, or those seeking a purely relaxing holiday.
packingEssentials: Warm layers for after water activities

stops.title: Surf Lesson at Llangennith
stops.description: Learn to surf at Wales' premier surf beach. Llangennith has consistent Atlantic swells and is ideal for beginners. 2-hour lessons include all equipment (wetsuit, board, boots) and qualified instruction. You'll be standing up by the end!
stops.insiderTip: Book the morning lesson - waves are often cleaner and the beach less crowded. PJ's Surf Shop at Hillend rents boards year-round if you want to practice later (from £15/day).

wetAlt.title: Gower Heritage Centre
wetAlt.description: Traditional working watermill with craft workshops, farm animals, and a good cafe. Family-friendly indoor option on a wet day.

budgetAlt.title: Self-guided surf (board hire only)
budgetAlt.description: Rent a board and wetsuit from PJ's Surf Shop and hit the waves yourself. Only if you have previous experience.

stops.title: King's Head (Llangennith)
stops.description: Classic Gower pub just up from the beach, popular with surfers. Good pub grub, local ales, and beer garden. The burgers are excellent fuel after surfing.

alternative.title: Edith's (Port Eynon)
alternative.description: Beach cafe with stunning views. Simple but excellent - try the crab rolls.

budgetAlt.title: Hillend Campsite Shop
budgetAlt.description: Basic supplies and hot drinks. Grab a pasty and eat on the dunes with ocean views.

stops.title: Rhossili Bay Walk & Worm's Head
stops.description: Walk the dramatic 3-mile sweep of Rhossili Bay (often voted Britain's best beach) then attempt the tidal crossing to Worm's Head - a serpent-shaped peninsula accessible only 2.5 hours either side of low tide. Check tide times before setting off!

tideInfo.note: Worm's Head crossing is ONLY possible 2.5 hours before and after low tide. Check tide times at the Coastwatch Lookout or online before attempting.

stops.insiderTip: The causeway is slippery - wear shoes with grip, not flip flops. Getting stranded is common - the NT Coastguard has rescued many people. Time it right and it's magical.

wetAlt.title: National Trust Visitor Centre
wetAlt.description: Learn about Gower's unique AONB status, shipwrecks, and wildlife. Small but interesting exhibition.

budgetAlt.title: Beach walk only
budgetAlt.description: Skip Worm's Head and just walk the beach. Equally stunning and you can go anytime regardless of tides.

stops.title: Hillend Campsite
stops.description: Legendary surf campsite right behind the dunes at Llangennith. Wake up to the sound of waves. Basic but brilliant - showers, toilets, small shop. Book pitch in advance for weekends.
stops.insiderTip: Pitch near the back for shelter from wind, or at the front for dawn surf checks from your tent. Gets busy on sunny weekends - book ahead or arrive early Friday.

budgetAlt.title: Wild camp (be responsible)
budgetAlt.description: Wild camping is technically not permitted but tolerated if you're discreet, leave no trace, and camp away from main paths. Please respect the AONB.

premiumAlt.title: King Arthur Hotel (Reynoldston)
premiumAlt.description: Charming country pub with rooms in the heart of Gower. Excellent restaurant, cosy rooms, real fires. Perfect after a day in the sea.

stops.title: Gower Coasteering
stops.description: Explore Gower's rugged coastline by jumping, swimming, and scrambling. Guided sessions take you to hidden coves, through sea caves, and off cliff jumps (all optional). All equipment provided including wetsuit, helmet, and buoyancy aid.

alternativeOperators.name: TYF Gower
alternativeOperators.notes: The original coasteering pioneers also operate on Gower

stops.insiderTip: All jumps are optional - guides will always offer an alternative route if you don't want to jump. The water feels cold at first but the wetsuit does its job. You'll be warm within 5 minutes.

wetAlt.title: Second surf session
wetAlt.description: Head back to Llangennith for another go at surfing. You'll be amazed how much you improve on day 2.

budgetAlt.title: Free wild swim at Fall Bay
budgetAlt.description: Hidden cove with natural arch. Bring your own kit and swim off the rocks. Beautiful but exposed - only for confident swimmers. Access via coastal path from Rhossili.

stops.title: Three Cliffs Coffee Shop
stops.description: Simple cafe near Three Cliffs Bay serving excellent toasties, cakes, and coffee. Small terrace with views. Perfect pit-stop before or after exploring the bay.

alternative.title: Pobbles Beach Cafe (if open)
alternative.description: Seasonal beach shack closer to the sand.

budgetAlt.title: Packed lunch on the beach
budgetAlt.description: Pick up supplies from Penmaen Stores and picnic on one of Gower's most beautiful beaches.

stops.title: Three Cliffs Bay Exploration
stops.description: End your trip at one of Britain's most photographed beaches. Three Cliffs Bay features three limestone peaks, a ruined castle, stepping stones across the river, and golden sand. Walk from Penmaen Burrows or Parkmill - the approach is part of the magic.
stops.costNote: Free access, parking £4-6 at Penmaen or Parkmill
stops.travelToNext: 1hr drive to Cardiff via M4, 1hr 30min to Bristol
stops.insiderTip: Low tide is best - you can walk all the way along the sand and cross the stepping stones. At high tide, the beach is smaller but you can still access via the sand dunes. Pennard Castle ruin on the cliff is worth the climb.

wetAlt.title: Mumbles exploration
wetAlt.description: Head to Mumbles for ice cream (Joe's is legendary), browse the independent shops, and walk the pier. Classic seaside town with cafes and pubs.

budget.notes: Camping, one surf lesson, packed lunches

premium.notes: Country hotel, all activities, restaurant meals

knowBeforeYouGo.weather: Gower has a mild climate but can be unpredictable. Sea temperatures are chilly (14-16°C in summer) but wetsuits make all activities comfortable. Coastal winds can be strong - great for surfing, not so great for beach lounging.
knowBeforeYouGo.traffic: The A4118 through Gower gets very congested on sunny weekends - allow extra time. Parking at popular beaches (Rhossili, Three Cliffs) fills by 10am in summer. Arrive early or use the Gower Explorer bus.
knowBeforeYouGo.booking: Surfing lessons and coasteering should be booked in advance, especially for weekends. Summer accommodation on Gower is in high demand - Hillend Campsite and popular campsites book up fast.
knowBeforeYouGo.fitness: A moderate level of fitness is required for coasteering and walking. Surfing is suitable for beginners but you'll use muscles you didn't know you had! The walk to Three Cliffs Bay involves some hills and sand dunes.
knowBeforeYouGo.tides: Check tide times for Worm's Head crossing (2.5 hours either side of low tide only). Three Cliffs Bay is more accessible at low tide. Surf is usually best on incoming tides with offshore (easterly) winds.
knowBeforeYouGo.gowerExplorer: The Gower Explorer bus runs in summer connecting Swansea with key Gower villages and beaches. Useful for linear coastal path walks or to avoid parking hassle.

addDay.title: Add SUP Adventure
addDay.description: Try stand-up paddleboarding in sheltered Oxwich Bay or Port Eynon. SUP Gower and others offer lessons and rentals.

alternative.title: Wild Swimming Trail
alternative.description: Swap coasteering for a self-guided wild swimming tour: Blue Pool (Broughton Bay), Fall Bay, and Pobbles Beach. Bring your own kit and adventure mindset.
